slides.title: Introduction to Indian History
slides.content:
Indian History is an important component of General Knowledge for Postal GDS exam. It covers thousands of years of Indian civilization, from ancient times to modern independence.

**Time Periods:**

**1. Ancient India (Up to 700 CE)**
- Indus Valley Civilization
- Vedic Period
- Mauryan Empire
- Gupta Empire

**2. Medieval India (700 CE - 1700 CE)**
- Delhi Sultanate
- Mughal Empire
- Regional Kingdoms

**3. Modern India (1700 CE - 1947)**
- British Rule
- Freedom Struggle
- Independence Movement

**4. Post-Independence (1947 onwards)**
- Nation building
- Constitutional development
- Modern India

**Why Important for Postal MTS?**
- 5-7 questions from history
- Focus on important dates and events
- Freedom fighters and their contributions
- Major dynasties and rulers
- Monuments and their builders

**Preparation Strategy:**
- Focus on important events and dates
- Remember key personalities
- Link events to their significance
- Make timeline charts
- Focus more on freedom struggle

History questions test factual knowledge, so memorization of key facts is important.

slides.title: Ancient India - Major Empires
slides.content:
**Indus Valley Civilization (3300-1300 BCE)**

**Important Sites:**
- Harappa (Pakistan) - First discovered
- Mohenjo-Daro (Pakistan) - Great Bath
- Lothal (Gujarat) - Dockyard
- Kalibangan (Rajasthan) - Fire altars
- Dholavira (Gujarat)
- Rakhigarhi (Haryana) - Largest site

**Features:**
- Advanced town planning
- Grid pattern streets
- Drainage system
- No evidence of weapons or temples

**Mauryan Empire (322-185 BCE)**

**Rulers:**
1. **Chandragupta Maurya** (322-298 BCE)
   - Founded empire with Chanakya's help
   - Defeated Seleucus
   - Wrote: Arthashastra (by Chanakya)

2. **Bindusara** (298-273 BCE)
   - Extended empire southward
   - "Amitraghata" (Slayer of enemies)

3. **Ashoka the Great** (268-232 BCE)
   - Most famous Mauryan ruler
   - Kalinga War (261 BCE) - turned to Buddhism
   - Rock edicts and pillar edicts
   - Sent Buddhist missions abroad
   - Ashoka Chakra - National Emblem

**Gupta Empire (320-550 CE) - Golden Age**

**Important Rulers:**
- Chandragupta I - Founder
- Samudragupta - "Napoleon of India"
- Chandragupta II (Vikramaditya) - Golden period

**Achievements:**
- Science and mathematics flourished
- Aryabhata - Mathematician
- Kalidasa - Poet and dramatist
- Iron Pillar at Delhi
- Ajanta and Ellora caves

slides.title: Medieval India - Delhi Sultanate and Mughals
slides.content:
**Delhi Sultanate (1206-1526)**

**Five Dynasties:**

**1. Slave/Mamluk Dynasty (1206-1290)**
- Qutub-ud-din Aibak - Built Qutub Minar
- Iltutmish - Consolidated sultanate
- Razia Sultan - First woman ruler

**2. Khilji Dynasty (1290-1320)**
- Alauddin Khilji - Most powerful
- Market control system
- Defeated Mongols

**3. Tughlaq Dynasty (1320-1414)**
- Muhammad bin Tughlaq - Token currency
- Shifted capital Delhi to Daulatabad

**4. Sayyid Dynasty (1414-1451)**
- Weak rulers

**5. Lodi Dynasty (1451-1526)**
- Ibrahim Lodi - Last sultan
- Defeated by Babur in 1526

**Mughal Empire (1526-1857)**

**Major Emperors:**

**1. Babur (1526-1530)**
- First Battle of Panipat - 1526
- Founded Mughal Empire
- Autobiography: Baburnama

**2. Humayun (1530-1556)**
- Lost to Sher Shah Suri
- Regained throne in 1555

**3. Akbar (1556-1605)**
- Greatest Mughal emperor
- Din-i-Ilahi (new religion)
- Abolished Jizya tax
- Nine Jewels (Navratnas) - Tansen, Birbal
- Built Fatehpur Sikri

**4. Jahangir (1605-1627)**
- Married Nur Jahan
- Justice-oriented rule

**5. Shah Jahan (1628-1658)**
- Built Taj Mahal (1632-1653)
- Red Fort, Jama Masjid
- Golden age of architecture

**6. Aurangzeb (1658-1707)**
- Last great Mughal
- Strict Islamic policies
- Reimposed Jizya
- Empire largest but declined after death

slides.title: Practice Questions
slides.content: Test your ancient and medieval history knowledge.

question.questionText: Who among the following built the Taj Mahal?
question.explanation: Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal in Agra (1632-1653) in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal. It is one of the Seven Wonders of the World.

slides.title: British Rule and Freedom Struggle
slides.content:
**British East India Company**

**Key Events:**
- 1600: Company established
- 1757: **Battle of Plassey** - Robert Clive defeated Siraj-ud-Daulah
- 1764: **Battle of Buxar**
- 1857: **First War of Independence** (Sepoy Mutiny)

**Revolt of 1857:**
- Started: May 10, 1857 in Meerut
- Mangal Pandey - First martyr
- Spread across North India
- Leaders: Rani Lakshmibai, Bahadur Shah Zafar, Tantia Tope, Nana Sahib
- Result: British Crown took direct control

**British Crown Rule (1858-1947)**

**Important Events:**

**1. Formation of Indian National Congress (1885)**
- Founded by A.O. Hume
- First President: W.C. Bonnerjee
- First session in Bombay

**2. Partition of Bengal (1905)**
- By Lord Curzon
- Led to Swadeshi Movement
- Annulled in 1911

**3. Jallianwala Bagh Massacre (1919)**
- General Dyer killed hundreds
- Amritsar, Punjab
- 13 April 1919

**4. Non-Cooperation Movement (1920-22)**
- Led by Gandhi
- Withdrawn after Chauri Chaura

**5. Simon Commission (1928)**
- All British commission
- "Simon Go Back" protests

**6. Dandi March (1930)**
- Salt Satyagraha
- 12 March to 6 April 1930
- 240 miles from Sabarmati to Dandi

**7. Quit India Movement (1942)**
- "Do or Die" call
- August 8, 1942
- Largest mass movement

slides.title: Freedom Fighters
slides.content:
**Major Freedom Fighters:**

**1. Mahatma Gandhi (1869-1948)**
- Father of the Nation
- Non-violent resistance
- Satyagraha philosophy
- Assassinated: January 30, 1948

**2. Jawaharlal Nehru (1889-1964)**
- First Prime Minister
- "Discovery of India" author
- Modern India's architect

**3. Subhas Chandra Bose (1897-1945)**
- "Netaji"
- Founded Indian National Army (INA)
- "Give me blood, I'll give you freedom"
- "Jai Hind" slogan

**4. Bhagat Singh (1907-1931)**
- Revolutionary
- Hanged at age 23
- "Inquilab Zindabad"

**5. Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel (1875-1950)**
- Iron Man of India
- United 562 princely states
- First Home Minister

**6. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar (1891-1956)**
- Father of Indian Constitution
- Social reformer
- Chairman of Drafting Committee

**7. Bal Gangadhar Tilak (1856-1920)**
- "Swaraj is my birthright"
- Father of Indian Unrest
- Started Ganeshotsav

**8. Lala Lajpat Rai (1865-1928)**
- Punjab Kesari (Lion of Punjab)
- Died protesting Simon Commission

**9. Rani Lakshmibai (1828-1858)**
- Queen of Jhansi
- 1857 revolt leader
- Symbol of bravery

**10. Mangal Pandey (1827-1857)**
- First martyr of 1857
- Soldier who revolted

**Important Slogans:**
- "Jai Hind" - Subhas Chandra Bose
- "Inquilab Zindabad" - Bhagat Singh
- "Swaraj is my birthright" - Tilak
- "Do or Die" - Gandhi
- "Jai Jawan Jai Kisan" - Lal Bahadur Shastri

question.questionText: When did the Quit India Movement begin?
question.explanation: The Quit India Movement began on August 8, 1942, when Mahatma Gandhi gave the 'Do or Die' call for immediate independence from British rule.

slides.title: Important Dates and Monuments
slides.content:
**Important Historical Dates:**

**Ancient & Medieval:**
- 326 BCE: Alexander's invasion
- 261 BCE: Kalinga War
- 1206: Delhi Sultanate begins
- 1526: First Battle of Panipat
- 1556: Second Battle of Panipat
- 1632-1653: Taj Mahal built

**British Period:**
- 1757: Battle of Plassey
- 1857: First War of Independence
- 1885: Indian National Congress formed
- 1905: Partition of Bengal
- 1919: Jallianwala Bagh Massacre
- 1930: Dandi March
- 1942: Quit India Movement
- 1947: Independence (15 August)

**Famous Monuments and Builders:**

**Delhi:**
- Qutub Minar - Qutub-ud-din Aibak
- Red Fort - Shah Jahan
- Jama Masjid - Shah Jahan
- India Gate - British (War Memorial)
- Lotus Temple - Bahai Faith

**Agra:**
- Taj Mahal - Shah Jahan
- Agra Fort - Akbar
- Fatehpur Sikri - Akbar

**Other Important:**
- Gateway of India (Mumbai) - British
- Charminar (Hyderabad) - Quli Qutb Shah
- Victoria Memorial (Kolkata) - British
- Konark Sun Temple (Odisha) - 13th century
- Ajanta-Ellora Caves (Maharashtra) - Ancient

**UNESCO World Heritage Sites in India:**
- Taj Mahal
- Qutub Minar
- Red Fort
- Ajanta-Ellora Caves
- Hampi monuments
- Fatehpur Sikri
- And many more (Total: 40+ sites)

**Remember:** Focus on builders and approximate periods of major monuments.
